msItem.textLang: Possibly Primitive Irish written in ogham script

support.p: Isle of Man Historic Environment Record (IOMHER): 1075.02
support.desc: The slab bears a cross carved in low relief on one face. The decorated side shows a shafted cross with limbs connected by a ring. Both the shaft and circle have a cable border ending at the foot in the head and tail of a serpent. In the centre of the cross is a circle of ring-chain, while each limb contains two interlinked rings bound by a diamond-shaped ring, and ends in four linked triquetras. The shaft is decorated with panels containing plaits of nine and seven strands. To the left of the shaft are a hart and hound, and a robed priest with arms raised, supported by a staff. On the right side are the worn remains of what may possibly be another hart and hound. Below them a seated man plays a harp to the right of whom another figure carries what appears to be a drinking horn. Below the harpist is another priest with uplifted arms, again holding a staff (IOMHER).

supportDesc.condition: The ogham alphabet inscription on the front of the slab is just legible by close scrutiny (Kermode 1910, 441). The second ogham inscription on the back of the slab, however, is now so badly weathered, as to be quite illegible (Kermode 1910, 441).

layoutDesc.layout: The first ogham inscription consists of the twenty letters of the ogham alphabet and is incised vertically on an artificial stemline in the space below the cross shaft and reads from below upwards (Kermode 1910, 441). The second ogham inscription is placed centrally between two runic inscriptions on the back of the slab near the top. The longer runic inscription is on the right and the shorter is to the left.

handDesc.handNote: The stemline for the ogham alphabet inscription has been deeply cut but the scores have been very finely made(Kermode 1910, 441). The second ogham inscription is only lightly scored or finely scratched as Kermode (1910, 441) notes.

history.provenance: This large slab was discovered in use as a lintel above a window in the old church in 1772. The first ogham text was first described by Lord Southesk in 1887, the second ogham text was discovered in 1907. Gibson (1722) only recorded the runes.
In the north transept of Kirk Michael church (MM 130).

div.p: 3) Runic: Mael Lomchon raised this cross to the memory of Malmura his foster mother, daughter of Dugald the wife whom Athisl had
4) Runic: Better is it to leave a good foster-son than a bad son

Later authorities have been unable to confirm Southesk's reading of the ogham text because of the poor legibility of the inscription. Kermode (1907, 101) notes that he was unable to make anything of it, except that it undoubtedly was an ogham inscription and West (2011) states that the 19th century reading cannot be relied on. The first element of the first name is a variation of the formula word MUCOI meaning 'descendant, litter of'. Southesk (1887, 360) notes that sometimes as a proper name it might represent a priestly designation. In both Welsh and Gaelic Mael or Maol signifies a servitor or attendant, more especially a tonsured servant, or the votary of a holy person (Southesk 1887, 359). In earlier compound names Mal more frequently represented Maglo or Mál, meaning 'a noble, a prince, a king'. Mael appears twice in the inscription as an element in each name. It is the suffix of the first name Mucomael and the prefix of the final name Maelguc. The general meaning of AFI or AVI appears to be Old Irish úa 'grandson', but it may sometimes signify nephew or descendent (Southesk 1887, 360).

The Norse inscription commemorating the errection of the cross dates the monument to the 11th century, and the Ogham inscriptions were evidently scratched onto the finished monument sometime later, so must date to the 11th century or later. The ogham inscriptions do not appear to have any relation to the Runic inscriptions. The use of a "feather mark" at the start of the Maughold inscription (M-IOM-006) and the use of bind letters in the Kirk Michael inscription may be indications that the Ogham alphabet scratched onto this stones may have been copied from a manuscript book such as the Auraicept na n-Éces ("Scholars' Primer"), and so they may reflect a pedantic interest in a script that was no longer used for commemorative inscriptions (West 2011).
